title: 103_s1178
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" and establishes the Great Lakes Research Council. The "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" establishes the Great Lakes Research Council to advise and coordinate Federal research activities for ecosystem protection of the Great Lakes. The Council is required to assess research activities needed to fulfill the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals and evaluate existing Federal expertise in those activities. The Great Lakes Research Council is tasked with assessing existing Federal research programs on the Great Lakes, making recommendations for research priorities, participating in research-related meetings and conferences, advising on data collection protocols, and cooperating in establishing a comprehensive data base for the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Research Council aims to assess Federal research programs, recommend priorities, participate in meetings, advise on data collection, and establish a comprehensive data base for the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Council consists of research managers from key agencies with expertise in the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Research Council consists of Federal agencies and other relevant departments, agencies, or instrumentalities as determined by the Council membership. Non-Federal employees may serve as ex officio members. The Chairperson is elected by the members for a two-year term, with a limit of two consecutive terms. Members are entitled to compensation for travel expenses. Interagency cooperation is required from all Council members. The Great Lakes Research Council requires cooperation from all members, including Federal agencies, to implement recommendations, provide necessary personnel or information, and assist in achieving the purposes of the Act. The Great Lakes Research Council requires international cooperation with the International Joint Commission serving as the principal coordinating body. Agencies on the Council may reimburse costs for activities. The Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to conduct Great Lakes research. The Great Lakes Research Council, established under the Act, defines the Great Lakes and Great Lakes research as the application of scientific expertise to understand the ecosystem. The bilateral agreement between the United States and Canada was signed in 1978 and amended in 1987.
